examples.title: Boston Marathon Finishers By Age and Gender
examples.author: Bill Mill
examples.note: This comparative histogram shows us that the older finishers are male, or it could be that older women do not even enter the race.

examples.title: Distribution of Marathon Finishing Times
examples.author: The New York Times
examples.note: The finishing times plotted here seem to follow a pattern - there is a drop in people finishing after every round number.

examples.title: Age Distribution of American Boys Named Joseph
examples.author: FiveThirtyEight
examples.note: The histogram shows the age distributions of all American men named Joseph who were alive in 2014. Most alive Josephs were 37 years old. Above the histogram, a line chart shows how many Josephs were born each year, with a peak in 1914.

examples.title: Age Distribution of American Girls Named Anna
examples.author: FiveThirtyEight
examples.note: The histogram shows the age distributions of all American women named Anna, who were alive in 2014. (Anna happens to be an extraordinarily enduring name, with about a quarter of Annas being under age 14 and a quarter over the age 62 in 2014. You can see this in the box plot examples.) Most alive Annas were 31 years old. Above the histogram, a line chart shows how many Annas were born a year.

examples.title: The Blue of 2015 Beijing Sky
examples.author: Yasai Wang
examples.note: This chart plots the level of air pollution (PM 2.5) against the color of the sky. The circular layout here creates the feeling of the cyclical nature of the calendar, but it also makes the bars of the histogram more difficult to compare. Still, we can see on a macro level that winter sees higher levels of pollution.

examples.title: Searching for Peace in Old Age
examples.author: Hyperakt
examples.note: Comparative histogram of age distribution now and in 2050 across all parts of the world.
